titleInfo.title: Influence of microRNA-21 on Vascular Function Following a Long-Term Atherogenic Diet

name.namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences

mods:mods.abstract: Atherosclerosis, an inflammatory disease of the arterial wall, is often identified as the major cause of cardiovascular disease (CVD). This disease of the arteries, resulting in the hardening and narrowing of the arterial lumen, is characterized by endothelial dysfunction, the accumulation of modified lipids, inflammatory cells, and plaque build-up. Obesity, Type 2 diabetes, smoking, and hypertension lead to an increase in vascular fibrosis and stiffening of the artery and therefore, increased risk of cardiovascular events. To avoid the progression of vascular stiffness and CVD, detecting vascular stiffness early on may play a critical role. This early detection allows for the necessary treatment and lifestyle interventions, which may assist in reducing risk factors associated with CVD. Vascular stiffness, or loss of elasticity in blood vessels, can be used as an independent early marker of atherosclerosis and predictor of cardiovascular events such as heart attacks and strokes. In addition to assessing vascular stiffness, this study will also investigate the role of microRNA-21 (miR-21) on female mice. miR-21 is a small non-coding RNA molecule that functions by binding most commonly to the 3' untranslated region (UTR) of the complementary sequences in messenger RNAs (mRNAs). miR-21 acts like an emergency brake for inflammation and may help prevent atherosclerotic plaques and therefore, the progression and development of CVD. The results of this study highlight the protective role inhibiting miR-21 has. The results showed the wild-type atherogenic diet group had the highest blood pressure while the miR-21 knockout atherogenic had the lowest blood pressure. Overall these findings suggest miR-21 knockout reduced body mass and body fat percent, which also aided in suppressing blood pressure in response to the atherogenic diet. Additionally, the protective role of miR-21 was also observed when checking vascular reactivity of the carotids, aortas, and mesenteric arteries highlighting a therapeutic target for regulating arterial compliance.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Justin LaFavor, Professor Directing Thesis; Michael Delp, Committee Member; Daniel Machin, Committee Member.
